Revealed: US Military Bought Mass Monitoring Tool That Includes Internet Browsing, Email Data6/29/2023

The “Augury” platform includes highly sensitive network data that Team Cymru, a private company, is selling to the military. “It’s everything. There’s nothing else to capture except the smell of electricity,” one cybersecurity expert said.

class="article__body-components article__body-components--longform"><div class="long-form__body-group"><div class="topic-callout"><div class="topic-callout__img"><a href="https://www.vice.com/en/topic/state-of-surveillance-2022"><img src="https://video-images.vice.com/topics/635027647ac4f3009a5e3f0d/callout_logo/1666991758264-final-02.png?resize=240:*" alt="final-02"/></a></div><div class="topic-callout__dek">This Series explores surveillance and its intersection with race and civil rights. made possible with support from Columbia University’s Ira A. Lipman Center.</div><div class="topic-callout__cta"><a href="https://www.vice.com/en/topic/state-of-surveillance-2022">See More →</a></div></div><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>Multiple branches of the U.S. military have bought access to a powerful internet monitoring tool that claims to cover over 90 percent of the world’s internet traffic, and which in some cases provides access to people’s email data, browsing history, and other information such as their sensitive internet cookies, according to contracting data and other documents reviewed by Motherboard. </p></span></div><div class=""><span><div class="adph adph--border"><div class="ac-w-ph__dsc">Advertisement</div><div class="ac-w-ph"><div class="ph ph-longform-top"><div class="vice-ad__container"><span class="vice-ad"></span></div></div></div></div></span></div><div class="long-form__body-group"><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>Additionally, Sen. Ron Wyden says that a whistleblower has contacted his office concerning the alleged warrantless use and purchase of this data by NCIS, a civilian law enforcement agency that’s part of the Navy, after filing a complaint through the official reporting process with the Department of Defense, <a href="https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/22670252-1763_001" target="_blank">according to a copy of the letter</a> shared by Wyden’s office with Motherboard.</p></span><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>The material reveals the sale and use of a previously little-known monitoring capability that is powered by data purchases from the private sector. The tool, called Augury, is developed by cybersecurity firm Team Cymru and bundles a massive amount of data and makes it available to government and corporate customers as a paid service. In the private industry, cybersecurity analysts use it for following hackers’ activity or attributing cyberattacks. In the government world, analysts can do the same, but agencies that deal with criminal investigations have also purchased the capability. The military agencies did not describe their use cases for the tool. However, the sale of the tool still highlights how Team Cymru obtains this controversial data and then sells it as a business, something that has alarmed multiple sources in the cybersecurity industry.</p></span><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>“The network data includes data from over 550 collection points worldwide, to include collection points in Europe, the Middle East, North/South America, Africa and Asia, and is updated with at least 100 billion new records each day,” a description of the Augury platform in <a href="https://sam.gov/opp/96b4874e76af45be90bb5a0b8b2bdb6b/view" target="_blank">a U.S. government procurement record</a> reviewed by Motherboard reads. It adds that Augury provides access to “petabytes” of current and historical data.</p></span></div><div class=""><span><div class="adph adph--border"><div class="ac-w-ph__dsc">Advertisement</div><div class="ac-w-ph"><div class="ph ph-longform-scroll"><div class="vice-ad__container"><span class="vice-ad"></span></div></div></div></div></span></div><div class="long-form__body-group"><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>Motherboard has found that the U.S. Navy, Army, Cyber Command, and the Defense Counterintelligence and Security Agency have collectively paid at least $3.5 million to access Augury. This allows the military to track internet usage using an incredible amount of sensitive information. Motherboard <a href="https://www.vice.com/en/article/n7wakg/cbp-dhs-location-data-venntel-apps">has extensively covered</a> how U.S. agencies gain access to data that in some cases would require a warrant or other legal mechanism by simply purchasing data that is available commercially from private companies. Most often, the sales center around location data harvested from smartphones. The Augury purchases show that this approach of buying access to data also extends to information more directly related to internet usage.</p></span><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>Team Cymru <a href="https://www.team-cymru.com/post/what-we-re-seeing-with-x-509-certificates-and-why-you-should-worry" target="_blank">says on its website that its solution provides</a> “access to a super majority of all activity on the internet.” </p></span><blockquote data-component="QuoteBlock" class="abc__quote abc__quote--blockquote"><p><em><strong>Do you work at a company that handles netflow data? Do you work at an ISP distributing that data? Or do you know anything else about the trade or use of netflow data? We'd love to hear from you. Using a non-work phone or computer, you can contact Joseph Cox securely on Signal on +44 20 8133 5190, Wickr on josephcox, or email joseph.cox@vice.com.</strong></em></p></blockquote><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>“Augury is the visibility into 93% of internet traffic,” another <a href="https://www.cosive.com/augury" target="_blank">website describing the tool reads</a>. Some clients have access to the platform under the different brand name Pure Signal RECON, <a href="https://www.team-cymru.com/post/what-we-re-seeing-with-x-509-certificates-and-why-you-should-worry" target="_blank">according to Team Cymru’s website</a>.</p></span></div><div class=""><span><div class="adph adph--border"><div class="ac-w-ph__dsc">Advertisement</div><div class="ac-w-ph"><div class="ph ph-longform-scroll"><div class="vice-ad__container"><span class="vice-ad"></span></div></div></div></div></span></div><div class="long-form__body-group"><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>The Augury platform makes a wide array of different types of internet data available to its users, according to online procurement records. These types of data include packet capture data (PCAP) related to email, remote desktop, and file sharing protocols. PCAP generally refers to a full capture of data and encompasses very detailed information about network activity. PCAP data includes the request sent from one server to another, and the response from that server too.</p></span><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>PCAP data is “everything,” Zach Edwards, a cybersecurity researcher who has closely followed the data trade, told Motherboard in an online chat. “It’s everything. There’s nothing else to capture except the smell of electricity.” (Team Cymru told Motherboard it does limit what data is returned to users but did not specify what data actually is provided to a user of the platform.)</p></span><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>A source in the cybersecurity industry said “that’s insane” when shown that sensitive information like PCAP data was available in Augury. Some private industry users appear to have less access to certain data types in Augury than those listed in the government procurement records. Motherboard granted multiple sources in this piece anonymity because they weren’t authorized by their employers to speak on this issue.</p></span><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>Augury’s data can also include web browser activity, like URLs visited and cookie usage, according to the procurement records. Cookies are sensitive files that websites plant onto computers when people visit them. Given their uniqueness, cookies can be effective for tracking. Facebook and Google, for example, use cookies to follow a particular user from website to website and track their activity. The NSA has then <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-switch/wp/2013/12/10/nsa-uses-google-cookies-to-pinpoint-targets-for-hacking/" target="_blank">piggybacked off of these cookies to identify targets for hacking</a>. Screenshots of an apparent Augury panel obtained by Motherboard show results containing cookies, URLs visited, and email data. Motherboard showed a section of one of the screenshots to multiple sources familiar with the tool who said it does appear to be the Augury panel. </p></span></div><div class=""><span><div class="adph adph--border"><div class="ac-w-ph__dsc">Advertisement</div><div class="ac-w-ph"><div class="ph ph-longform-scroll"><div class="vice-ad__container"><span class="vice-ad"></span></div></div></div></div></span></div><div class="long-form__body-group"><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p><em><strong><a href="https://link1.vice.com/join/6qz/signup-motherboard">Sign up for Motherboard’s daily newsletter</a> for a regular dose of our original reporting, plus behind-the-scenes content about our biggest stories.</strong></em></p></span><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>Augury also contains so-called netflow data, which creates a picture of traffic flow and volume across a network. That can include which server communicated with another, which is information that may ordinarily only be available to the server owner themselves or to the internet service provider carrying the traffic. That netflow data can be used for following traffic through virtual private networks, and show the server they are ultimately connecting from. Multiple sources in the cybersecurity industry told Motherboard that netflow data can be useful for identifying infrastructure that hackers are using.</p></span><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>Team Cymru obtains this netflow data from ISPs; in return, Team Cymru provides the ISPs with threat intelligence. That transfer of data is likely happening without the informed consent of the ISPs’ users. A source familiar with the netflow data <a href="https://www.vice.com/en/article/jg84yy/data-brokers-netflow-data-team-cymru">previously told Motherboard</a> that “the users almost certainly don’t [know]” their data is being provided to Team Cymru, who then sells access to it. </p></span><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>It is not clear where exactly Team Cymru obtains the PCAP and other more sensitive information, whether that's from ISPs or another method.</p></span></div><div class=""><div class="body-image" data-component="ImageBlock"><div class="body-image__img"><div><picture class="responsive-image lazyloader--lazy lazyloader--lowres"><source media="(min-width: 1000px)" srcSet="https://video-images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1663773244353-traffic.jpeg?resize=20:*"/><source media="(min-width: 700px)" srcSet="https://video-images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1663773244353-traffic.jpeg?resize=20:*"/><source media="(min-width: 0px)" srcSet="https://video-images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1663773244353-traffic.jpeg?resize=20:*"/><img class="responsive-image__img" alt="traffic.jpg" decoding="async" loading="eager" width="1036" height="508"/></picture></div></div><div class="body-image__caption"><p>A screenshot of Augury obtained by Motherboard. Image: Motherboard.</p></div></div></div><div class="long-form__body-group"><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>Motherboard asked Team Cymru multiple times if Augury contains cookies, URLs visited, and PCAP data, as the procurement records show. Team Cymru did not answer the question directly, and instead wrote in an email that “The Augury platform is not designed to target specific users or user activity. The platform specifically does not possess subscriber information necessary to tie records back to any users.”</p></span></div><div class=""><span><div class="adph adph--border"><div class="ac-w-ph__dsc">Advertisement</div><div class="ac-w-ph"><div class="ph ph-longform-scroll"><div class="vice-ad__container"><span class="vice-ad"></span></div></div></div></div></span></div><div class="long-form__body-group"><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>“Our platform does not provide user or subscriber information, and it doesn’t provide results that show any pattern of life, preventing its ability to be used to target individuals. Our platform only captures a limited sampling of the available data, and is further restricted by only allowing queries against restricted sampled and limited data, which all originates from malware, malicious activity, honeypots, scans, and third parties who provide feeds of the same. Results are then further limited in the scope and volume of what’s returned,” Team Cymru said in another email. </p></span><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>Some have used Team Cymru’s data as part of investigations that aimed to identify specific computers and then contact the person using it, though. In July 2021 researchers at Citizen Lab <a href="https://citizenlab.ca/2021/07/hooking-candiru-another-mercenary-spyware-vendor-comes-into-focus/" target="_blank">published a report</a> about Israeli spyware vendor Candiru. As part of that, the researchers wrote that they used Team Cymru’s data to identify a computer they believed had been infected with Candiru’s malware, and in turn, contacted the owner of that computer. Citizen Lab did not respond to a request for comment.</p></span><div class="article__embed-component" data-component="OEmbedBlock"><div class="article__embed-component__content"><div><div style="left: 0; width: 100%; height: 0; position: relative; padding-bottom: 56.25%;"><iframe data-iframely-url="//oembed.vice.com/TGoJLy2?playerjs=1" data-img style="top: 0; left: 0; width: 100%; height: 100%; position: absolute; border: 0;" allowfullscreen scrolling="no" allow="autoplay *; accelerometer *; clipboard-write *; encrypted-media *; gyroscope *; picture-in-picture *;"></iframe></div></div></div></div><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>The procurement record that says Augury has access to PCAP data, URLs visited, and cookies relates to the maintenance of a Department of the Navy purchase of the tool. Other procurement data viewed by Motherboard shows the Department of the Navy paid for a “Platinum” Augury license. Beyond that, it is not clear which of Team Cymru’s U.S. government clients have access to the more sensitive data such as cookies. Records for the Army, Cyber Command, and the Defense Counterintelligence and Security Agency do not explicitly include the “platinum” marker, but in some cases the amount paid by the agencies is the same amount the Navy paid for a platinum license.</p></span></div><div class=""><span><div class="adph adph--border"><div class="ac-w-ph__dsc">Advertisement</div><div class="ac-w-ph"><div class="ph ph-longform-scroll"><div class="vice-ad__container"><span class="vice-ad"></span></div></div></div></div></span></div><div class="long-form__body-group"><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>These sales to the U.S. government were made through a company called Argonne Ridge Group, which Motherboard found shares an address with Team Cymru. Team Cymru told Motherboard in an email that Argonne Ridge Group is an affiliate of Team Cymru which has historically handled contracts with public agencies.</p></span><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>Although they don’t explicitly mention Augury, Motherboard found multiple contracts between Argonne Ridge Group and the FBI and Secret Service. One of the FBI contracts says “it will secure funding approval to buy net flow from one commercial vendor and integrating it into existing sources of net flow available to cyber intelligence analysts to analyze as a proof of concept.” The Secret Service did not respond to multiple requests for comment. The FBI did not provide a response in time for publication.</p></span><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>The Army was unable to provide a statement on the Augury platform purchases in time for publication. After initially acknowledging Motherboard’s request for comment, the Defense Counterintelligence and Security Agency later deferred to the Department of Defense.</p></span><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>Charles E. Spirtos from the Navy Office of Information told Motherboard in an email that NCIS specifically “conducts investigations and operations in accordance with all applicable laws and regulations. The use of net flow data by NCIS does not require a warrant.” Spirtos added that NCIS has not used netflow during any criminal investigation, but that “NCIS uses net flow data for various counterintelligence purposes.”</p></span></div><div class=""><span><div class="adph adph--border"><div class="ac-w-ph__dsc">Advertisement</div><div class="ac-w-ph"><div class="ph ph-longform-scroll"><div class="vice-ad__container"><span class="vice-ad"></span></div></div></div></div></span></div><div class="long-form__body-group"><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>Regarding the whistleblower that Senator Wyden says approached his office, their complaint relates specifically to use by NCIS, which Motherboard found does have a contract with Argonne Ridge Group.</p></span><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>“NCIS will defeat threats from across the foreign intelligence, terrorist and criminal spectrum by conducting operations and investigations ashore, afloat, and in cyberspace, in order to protect and preserve the superiority of the Navy and Marine Corps warfighters,” NCIS’ website reads.</p></span><div class="abc__article_embed" data-component="RelatedArticleBlock"><div class="vice-card vice-card--light"><div class="vice-card__content"><div class="vice-card-rubric vice-card-rubric--light vice-card__vice-card-rubric"><a class="vice-card-rubric__label vice-card-rubric__link" href="/en/section/tech">Tech</a></div><h3 class="vice-card-hed vice-card-hed--light vice-card__vice-card-hed"><a href="/en/article/jg84yy/data-brokers-netflow-data-team-cymru" class="vice-card-hed__link">How Data Brokers Sell Access to the Backbone of the Internet</a></h3><div class="vice-card-details vice-card-details--light vice-card__vice-card-details"><div class="vice-card-details__byline">Joseph Cox</div><time class="vice-card-details__pub-date" dateTime="2021-08-24T13:31">08.24.21</time></div></div><div class="vice-card-image vice-card__vice-card-image"><a href="/en/article/jg84yy/data-brokers-netflow-data-team-cymru" class="vice-card-image__link" tabindex="-1"><div class="vice-card-image__placeholder-image placeholder-image--16-9--sm placeholder-image--16-9--md placeholder-image--16-9--lg"><div><picture class="responsive-image lazyloader--lazy"><source media="(min-width: 1000px)" srcSet="data://image/png;base64," width="700" height="393.75"/><source media="(min-width: 700px)" srcSet="data://image/png;base64," width="400" height="225"/><source media="(min-width: 0px)" srcSet="data://image/png;base64," width="200" height="112.5"/><img class="responsive-image__img" alt="" decoding="async" loading="eager"/></picture></div></div></a></div></div></div><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>In his letter addressed to the oversight departments of the DHS, DOJ, and DOD, Senator Wyden writes that “my office was recently contacted by a whistleblower who described a series of formal complaints they filed up and down their chain of command, as well as to the DOD Inspector General and the Defense Intelligence Agency, regarding the warrantless purchase and use of netflow data by the Naval Criminal Investigative Service (NCIS).” </p></span><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>The whistleblower alleges that NCIS is purchasing data from Team Cymru that includes both “netflow records and some communications content,” the letter continues. “The whistleblower has informed my office that their complaint was forwarded by the DOD Inspector General to the Navy Inspector General.” Pointing to the various U.S. government contracts for access to Augury, which his office also reviewed, in his letter Senator Wyden asks the oversight branches of the DHS, DOJ, and DOD to “investigate the warrantless purchase and use of Americans’ internet browsing records by the agencies under your jurisdictions. Your independent oversight must ensure that the government’s surveillance activities are consistent with the Supreme Court’s Carpenter decision and safeguard Americans’ Fourth Amendment rights.” </p></span></div><div class=""><span><div class="adph adph--border"><div class="ac-w-ph__dsc">Advertisement</div><div class="ac-w-ph"><div class="ph ph-longform-scroll"><div class="vice-ad__container"><span class="vice-ad"></span></div></div></div></div></span></div><div class="long-form__body-group"><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>The Department of Defense Office of the Inspector General, which the whistleblower alleges referred their complaint to the Navy, told Motherboard it had received Wyden’s letter and was reviewing it. The Office of the Naval Inspector General declined to comment and directed Motherboard back to its Department of Defense counterpart.</p></span><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>Beyond his day job as CEO of Team Cymru, Rabbi Rob Thomas also sits on the board of the Tor Project, a privacy focused non-profit that maintains the Tor software. That software is what underpins the Tor anonymity network, <a href="https://metrics.torproject.org/networksize.html" target="_blank">a collection of thousands of volunteer-run servers</a> that allow anyone to anonymously browse the internet. </p></span><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>“Just like Tor users, the developers, researchers, and founders who've made Tor possible are a diverse group of people. But all of the people who have been involved in Tor are united by a common belief: internet users should have private access to an uncensored web,” <a href="https://www.torproject.org/about/history/" target="_blank">the Tor Project’s website reads</a>. </p></span><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>When asked by Motherboard in April about Thomas’ position on the Tor Project board while also being the CEO of a company that sells a capability for attributing activity on the internet, Isabela Bagueros, executive director for the Tor Project, said in an email that “Rabbi Rob's potential conflicts of interest have been vetted according to the standard conflicts disclosure process required of all board members. Based on the board's understanding of Rabbi Rob's work with Team Cymru, the board has not identified any conflicts of interest.”</p></span><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>Motherboard has previously revealed other data purchases by the U.S. military. In 2020, <a href="https://www.vice.com/en/article/jgqm5x/us-military-location-data-xmode-locate-x">Motherboard found that a Muslim prayer app</a> downloaded more than 98 million times sold its location data to a broker called X-Mode. X-Mode, in turn, included U.S. military contractors among its clients. As part of that investigation, Motherboard also found that U.S. Special Operations Command had purchased Locate X, a surveillance tool based on location data harvested from ordinary apps. Last March, <a href="https://www.vice.com/en/article/y3g97x/location-data-apps-drone-strikes-iowa-national-guard">Motherboard reported that a military unit that conducts drone strikes</a> bought Locate X too.</p></span><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>After Motherboard published some of those findings, Sen. Wyden asked the Department of Defense for more information about its data purchases. Some of the agency’s subsequent responses were given in a form that meant Wyden's office could not legally publish specifics on the surveillance; one answer in particular was classified. Instead, <a href="https://www.vice.com/en/article/88ng8x/pentagon-americans-surveillance-without-warrant-internet-browsing">Wyden wrote in a second letter in May 2021 to the agency</a>: “I write to urge you to release to the public information about the Department of Defense's (DoD) warrantless surveillance of Americans,” suggesting that the Pentagon is engaged in such surveillance. At the time, Wyden's office declined to provide Motherboard with specifics about the classified answer. But a Wyden aide said that the question related to the Department of Defense buying internet metadata.</p></span><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>In August, the House of Representatives approved changes to next year’s military budget that would require the Department of Defense to start to disclose any purchases of web browsing or smartphone data that would ordinarily require a warrant, <em><a href="https://gizmodo.com/pentagon-budget-force-data-purchase-disclosure-ndaa-1849432085" target="_blank">Gizmodo </a></em><a href="https://gizmodo.com/pentagon-budget-force-data-purchase-disclosure-ndaa-1849432085" target="_blank">reported at the time</a>. It has yet to be approved by the Senate.</p></span><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>Other cybersecurity companies also package controversial datasets. In 2020 <a href="https://www.vice.com/en/article/qj454d/private-intelligence-location-data-xmode-hyas">Motherboard reported that HYAS</a>, a threat intelligence firm, sourced location data in order to track people to their “doorstep.”</p></span><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p><em>Update: This piece has been updated with a statement from the Navy.</em></p></span><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p><em><strong>This article is part of <a href="https://www.vice.com/en/topic/state-of-surveillance-2022">State of Surveillance</a>, made possible with the support of a grant from Columbia University’s Ira A. Lipman Center for Journalism and Civil and Human Rights in conjunction with Arnold Ventures. The series will explore the development, deployment, and effects of surveillance and its intersection with race and civil rights.</strong></em></p></span></div></div><div The tool, called Augury, is developed by cybersecurity firm Team Cymru and bundles a massive amount of data and makes it available to government and corporate customers as a paid service. In the private industry, cybersecurity analysts use it for following hackers’ activity or attributing cyberattacks. In the government world, analysts can do the same, but agencies that deal with criminal investigations have also purchased the capability. The military agencies did not describe their use cases for the tool. However, the sale of the tool still highlights how Team Cymru obtains this controversial data and then sells it as a business, something that has alarmed multiple sources in the cybersecurity industry.\",\"text\":\"The material reveals the sale and use of a previously little-known monitoring capability that is powered by data purchases from the private sector. The tool, called Augury, is developed by cybersecurity firm Team Cymru and bundles a massive amount of data and makes it available to government and corporate customers as a paid service. In the private industry, cybersecurity analysts use it for following hackers\u0026#x2019; activity or attributing cyberattacks. In the government world, analysts can do the same, but agencies that deal with criminal investigations have also purchased the capability. The military agencies did not describe their use cases for the tool. However, the sale of the tool still highlights how Team Cymru obtains this controversial data and then sells it as a business, something that has alarmed multiple sources in the cybersecurity industry.\",\"dropcap\":false,\"charscount\":872,\"wordscount\":137},{\"id\":\"63613d093d7f800093e2b1da\",\"version\":\"1\",\"position\":3,\"role\":\"body\",\"html\":\"“The network data includes data from over 550 collection points worldwide, to include collection points in Europe, the Middle East, North/South America, Africa and Asia, and is updated with at least 100 billion new records each day,” a description of the Augury platform in \u003ca href=\\\"https://sam.gov/opp/96b4874e76af45be90bb5a0b8b2bdb6b/view\\\"\u003ea U.S. government procurement record\u003c/a\u003e reviewed by Motherboard reads. It adds that Augury provides access to “petabytes” of current and historical data.\",\"text\":\"\u0026#x201c;The network data includes data from over 550 collection points worldwide, to include collection points in Europe, the Middle East, North/South America, Africa and Asia, and is updated with at least 100 billion new records each day,\u0026#x201d; a description of the Augury platform in [a U.S. government procurement record](https://sam.gov/opp/96b4874e76af45be90bb5a0b8b2bdb6b/view) reviewed by Motherboard reads. It adds that Augury provides access to \u0026#x201c;petabytes\u0026#x201d; of current and historical data.\",\"dropcap\":false,\"charscount\":465,\"wordscount\":74},{\"id\":\"63613d093d7f800093e2b1db\",\"version\":\"1\",\"position\":4,\"role\":\"body\",\"html\":\"Motherboard has found that the U.S. Navy, Army, Cyber Command, and the Defense Counterintelligence and Security Agency have collectively paid at least $3.5 million to access Augury. This allows the military to track internet usage using an incredible amount of sensitive information. Motherboard \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.vice.com/en/article/n7wakg/cbp-dhs-location-data-venntel-apps\\\"\u003ehas extensively covered\u003c/a\u003e how U.S. agencies gain access to data that in some cases would require a warrant or other legal mechanism by simply purchasing data that is available commercially from private companies. Most often, the sales center around location data harvested from smartphones. The Augury purchases show that this approach of buying access to data also extends to information more directly related to internet usage.\",\"text\":\"Motherboard has found that the U.S. Navy, Army, Cyber Command, and the Defense Counterintelligence and Security Agency have collectively paid at least $3.5 million to access Augury. PCAP generally refers to a full capture of data and encompasses very detailed information about network activity. PCAP data includes the request sent from one server to another, and the response from that server too.\",\"text\":\"The Augury platform makes a wide array of different types of internet data available to its users, according to online procurement records. The NSA has then \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-switch/wp/2013/12/10/nsa-uses-google-cookies-to-pinpoint-targets-for-hacking/\\\"\u003epiggybacked off of these cookies to identify targets for hacking\u003c/a\u003e. Screenshots of an apparent Augury panel obtained by Motherboard show results containing cookies, URLs visited, and email data. Motherboard showed a section of one of the screenshots to multiple sources familiar with the tool who said it does appear to be the Augury panel.\u0026nbsp;\",\"text\":\"Augury\u0026#x2019;s data can also include web browser activity, like URLs visited and cookie usage, according to the procurement records. That can include which server communicated with another, which is information that may ordinarily only be available to the server owner themselves or to the internet service provider carrying the traffic. That netflow data can be used for following traffic through virtual private networks, and show the server they are ultimately connecting from. The platform specifically does not possess subscriber information necessary to tie records back to any users.\u0026#x201d;\",\"dropcap\":false,\"charscount\":429,\"wordscount\":68},{\"id\":\"63613d093d7f800093e2b1e9\",\"version\":\"1\",\"position\":18,\"role\":\"body\",\"html\":\"“Our platform does not provide user or subscriber information, and it doesn’t provide results that show any pattern of life, preventing its ability to be used to target individuals. Our platform only captures a limited sampling of the available data, and is further restricted by only allowing queries against restricted sampled and limited data, which all originates from malware, malicious activity, honeypots, scans, and third parties who provide feeds of the same. Results are then further limited in the scope and volume of what’s returned,” Team Cymru said in another email.\u0026nbsp;\",\"text\":\"\u0026#x201c;Our platform does not provide user or subscriber information, and it doesn\u0026#x2019;t provide results that show any pattern of life, preventing its ability to be used to target individuals. height: 100%; position: absolute; border: 0;\\\" allowfullscreen scrolling=\\\"no\\\" allow=\\\"autoplay *; accelerometer *; clipboard-write *; encrypted-media *; gyroscope *; picture-in-picture *;\\\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\",\"type\":\"video\",\"title\":\"Augury is context from a million facts per second\",\"author\":\"Team Cymru\",\"version\":\"1.0\",\"cache_age\":86400,\"author_url\":\"https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC8xFhiG1tn_Jo4QRBgm_aSQ\",\"description\":\"There are over seven hundred thousand miles of submarine fiber optic sales crossing our planet, and sometimes shadowy submarines are thought to interfere with them.\\n\\nSee this warning from back in 2017 from the UK's most senior military officer at the time, Air Chief Marshal Sir Stuart Peach, the chief of the defence staff, about Russian submarines and a need for Nato to prioritize protecting the lines of communication: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TSdTByyLWXc\\n\\nTeam Cymru prefers to take the high road to get you access to the same data in a way that you can use to power your Network Operations Centers and Security Operations Centers and attributive analysis needs. \\n\\nOver 50 different datasets covering a million facts per second means your analysts get access to the only tool that covers network traffic from, well, pretty much everywhere. reach out to Team Cymru and let us show you what this new to market commercial context can do for you: https://www.team-cymru.com/products.html\",\"provider_name\":\"YouTube\",\"thumbnail_url\":\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/vEFpAlSaCv4/maxresdefault.jpg\",\"thumbnail_width\":1280,\"thumbnail_height\":720},\"provider_id\":\"vEFpAlSaCv4\"},{\"id\":\"63613d093d7f800093e2b1eb\",\"version\":\"1\",\"position\":21,\"role\":\"body\",\"html\":\"The procurement record that says Augury has access to PCAP data, URLs visited, and cookies relates to the maintenance of a Department of the Navy purchase of the tool. Other procurement data viewed by Motherboard shows the Department of the Navy paid for a “Platinum” Augury license. Beyond that, it is not clear which of Team Cymru’s U.S. government clients have access to the more sensitive data such as cookies. Records for the Army, Cyber Command, and the Defense Counterintelligence and Security Agency do not explicitly include the “platinum” marker, but in some cases the amount paid by the agencies is the same amount the Navy paid for a platinum license.\",\"text\":\"The procurement record that says Augury has access to PCAP data, URLs visited, and cookies relates to the maintenance of a Department of the Navy purchase of the tool. Other procurement data viewed by Motherboard shows the Department of the Navy paid for a \u0026#x201c;Platinum\u0026#x201d; Augury license. Beyond that, it is not clear which of Team Cymru\u0026#x2019;s U.S. government clients have access to the more sensitive data such as cookies. Records for the Army, Cyber Command, and the Defense Counterintelligence and Security Agency do not explicitly include the \u0026#x201c;platinum\u0026#x201d; marker, but in some cases the amount paid by the agencies is the same amount the Navy paid for a platinum license.\",\"dropcap\":false,\"charscount\":714,\"wordscount\":123},{\"id\":\"63613d093d7f800093e2b1ec\",\"version\":\"1\",\"position\":22,\"role\":\"body\",\"html\":\"These sales to the U.S. government were made through a company called Argonne Ridge Group, which Motherboard found shares an address with Team Cymru. Team Cymru told Motherboard in an email that Argonne Ridge Group is an affiliate of Team Cymru which has historically handled contracts with public agencies.\",\"text\":\"These sales to the U.S. government were made through a company called Argonne Ridge Group, which Motherboard found shares an address with Team Cymru. Team Cymru told Motherboard in an email that Argonne Ridge Group is an affiliate of Team Cymru which has historically handled contracts with public agencies.\",\"dropcap\":false,\"charscount\":308,\"wordscount\":50},{\"id\":\"63613d093d7f800093e2b1ed\",\"version\":\"1\",\"position\":23,\"role\":\"body\",\"html\":\"Although they don’t explicitly mention Augury, Motherboard found multiple contracts between Argonne Ridge Group and the FBI and Secret Service. One of the FBI contracts says “it will secure funding approval to buy net flow from one commercial vendor and integrating it into existing sources of net flow available to cyber intelligence analysts to analyze as a proof of concept.” The Secret Service did not respond to multiple requests for comment. The FBI did not provide a response in time for publication.\",\"text\":\"Although they don\u0026#x2019;t explicitly mention Augury, Motherboard found multiple contracts between Argonne Ridge Group and the FBI and Secret Service. One of the FBI contracts says \u0026#x201c;it will secure funding approval to buy net flow from one commercial vendor and integrating it into existing sources of net flow available to cyber intelligence analysts to analyze as a proof of concept.\u0026#x201d; The Secret Service did not respond to multiple requests for comment. The FBI did not provide a response in time for publication.\",\"dropcap\":false,\"charscount\":538,\"wordscount\":89},{\"id\":\"63613d093d7f800093e2b1ee\",\"version\":\"1\",\"position\":24,\"role\":\"body\",\"html\":\"The Army was unable to provide a statement on the Augury platform purchases in time for publication. After initially acknowledging Motherboard’s request for comment, the Defense Counterintelligence and Security Agency later deferred to the Department of Defense.\",\"text\":\"The Army was unable to provide a statement on the Augury platform purchases in time for publication. After initially acknowledging Motherboard\u0026#x2019;s request for comment, the Defense Counterintelligence and Security Agency later deferred to the Department of Defense.\",\"dropcap\":false,\"charscount\":273,\"wordscount\":40},{\"id\":\"63613d093d7f800093e2b1ef\",\"version\":\"1\",\"position\":25,\"role\":\"body\",\"html\":\"Charles E. Spirtos from the Navy Office of Information told Motherboard in an email that NCIS specifically “conducts investigations and operations in accordance with all applicable laws and regulations.\u0026nbsp;The use of net flow data by NCIS does not require a warrant.” Spirtos added that NCIS has not used netflow during any criminal investigation, but that “NCIS uses net flow data for various counterintelligence purposes.”\",\"text\":\"Charles E. Spirtos from the Navy Office of Information told Motherboard in an email that NCIS specifically \u0026#x201c;conducts investigations and operations in accordance with all applicable laws and regulations. The use of net flow data by NCIS does not require a warrant.\u0026#x201d; Spirtos added that NCIS has not used netflow during any criminal investigation, but that \u0026#x201c;NCIS uses net flow data for various counterintelligence purposes.\u0026#x201d;\",\"dropcap\":false,\"charscount\":462,\"wordscount\":73},{\"id\":\"63613d093d7f800093e2b1f0\",\"version\":\"1\",\"position\":26,\"role\":\"body\",\"html\":\"Regarding the whistleblower that Senator Wyden says approached his office, their complaint relates specifically to use by NCIS, which Motherboard found does have a contract with Argonne Ridge Group.\",\"text\":\"Regarding the whistleblower that Senator Wyden says approached his office, their complaint relates specifically to use by NCIS, which Motherboard found does have a contract with Argonne Ridge Group.\",\"dropcap\":false,\"charscount\":199,\"wordscount\":29},{\"id\":\"63613d093d7f800093e2b1f1\",\"version\":\"1\",\"position\":27,\"role\":\"body\",\"html\":\"“NCIS will defeat threats from across the foreign intelligence, terrorist and criminal spectrum by conducting operations and investigations ashore, afloat, and in cyberspace, in order to protect and preserve the superiority of the Navy and Marine Corps warfighters,” NCIS’ website reads.\",\"text\":\"\u0026#x201c;NCIS will defeat threats from across the foreign intelligence, terrorist and criminal spectrum by conducting operations and investigations ashore, afloat, and in cyberspace, in order to protect and preserve the superiority of the Navy and Marine Corps warfighters,\u0026#x201d; NCIS\u0026#x2019; website reads.\",\"dropcap\":false,\"charscount\":318,\"wordscount\":47},{\"id\":\"63613d093d7f800093e2b1f2\",\"version\":\"1\",\"position\":28,\"role\":\"article\",\"site\":\"vice\",\"locale\":\"en_us\",\"web_id\":\"jg84yy\",\"display\":\"inline\",\"article_id\":\"6124f0340e8ea2009b051181\",\"article\":{\"id\":\"6124f0340e8ea2009b051181\",\"body\":\"\u003cp\u003eThere's something of an open secret in the cybersecurity world: internet service providers quietly give away detailed information about which computer is communicating with another to private businesses, which then sells access to that data to a range of third parties, according to multiple sources in the threat intelligence industry.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eThe information, known as netflow data, is a useful tool for digital investigators. They can use it to identify servers being used by hackers, or to follow data as it is stolen. But the sale of this information still makes some people nervous because they are concerned about whose hands it may fall into.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003e\\\"I'm concerned that netflow data being offered for commercial purposes is a path to a dark fucking place,\\\" one source familiar with the data told Motherboard. Motherboard granted multiple sources anonymity to speak more candidly about industry issues.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eAt a high level, netflow data creates a picture of traffic flow and volume across a network. It can show which server communicated with another, information that may ordinarily only be available to the server owner or the ISP carrying the traffic. Crucially, this data can be used for, among other things, tracking traffic through virtual private networks, which are used to mask where someone is connecting to a server from, and by extension, their approximate physical location.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eTeam Cymru, one threat intelligence firm, works with ISPs to access that netflow data, three sources said. Keith Chu, communications director for the office of Senator Ron Wyden which has been conducting its own investigations into the sale of sensitive data, added that Team Cymru told the office \\\"it obtains netflow data from third parties in exchange for threat intelligence.\\\"\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp class=\\\"article__blockquote\\\"\u003e\u003ci\u003e\u003cb\u003eDo you work at a company that handles netflow data? Do you work at an ISP distributing that data? Or do you know anything else about the trade of netflow data? We'd love to hear from you. Using a non-work phone or computer, you can contact Joseph Cox securely on Signal on +44 20 8133 5190, Wickr on josephcox, or email joseph.cox@vice.com.\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/i\u003e\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eCompanies that may source Team Cymru's data include cybersecurity firms hired to respond to data breaches or proactively hunt out hackers. \u003ca href=\\\"https://team-cymru.com/company/careers/\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eOn its website\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e, Team Cymru says it works with both public and private sector teams to \\\"to help identify, track and stop bad actors both in cyber space and on the ground.\\\"\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003e\\\"I'm less worried about a bad guy hacker and more worried about a bad guy government or company or politician,\\\" one source familiar with the data said. A source in the threat intelligence industry added that they \\\"always thought it was kinda bonkers,\\\" referring to Team Cymru's sale of netflow data.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eThe continued sale of sensitive data could present its own privacy and security concerns, and the news highlights that ISPs are providing this data at scale to third parties likely without the informed consent of their own users. Other companies, such as cybersecurity firm Palo Alto Networks, also have access to netflow data.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003e\\\"The users almost certainly don't [know]\\\" their data is being provided to Team Cymru, who then sells access to it, the source familiar with the data said.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cdiv class=\\\"article__embed article__embed--vice\\\" data-related-article=\\\"true\\\" data-children-count=\\\"0\\\"\u003e\u003ciframe src=\\\"https://www.vice.com/en_us/embed/article/qj454d/embed\\\" frameborder=\\\"0\\\" style=\\\"border:0px none;margin:0px\\\" allowfullscreen\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/div\u003e \u003cp\u003eTeam Cymru's customers can probe a dataset, and \\\"effectively run queries against virtually any IP to pull the netflows to and from that IP over a given point in time,\\\" one of the sources said. Chu added Team Cymru said it \\\"restricts the amount of data that is returned, so that only a small portion of the netflow data in its database can be accessed by any one client.\\\"\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eIn product descriptions, Team Cymru offers users the ability to follow traffic through VPNs, which attackers may use to cover their tracks or ordinary people to browse the internet more privately.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003e\\\"Trace malicious activity through a dozen or more proxies and VPNs to identify the origin of a cyber threat,\\\" one brochure for a Team Cymru product called Pure Signal Recon reads. In essence, access to netflow data lets a security team observe what is happening on the wider internet, and may indicate what is happening to other organizations, beyond the borders of their own network or company. One of the sources said they previously saw traffic from an organization they knew inside Team Cymru's dataset and was spooked by it at the time.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003e\\\"Visibility and insight are global,\\\" the description adds. An image included in the brochure shows Team Cymru's product letting users trace the activity of servers linked to an Iranian hacking group further than other datasets, such as DNS lookups.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cdiv class=\\\"article__media\\\"\u003e\u003cpicture class=\\\"article__image\\\"\u003e\u003csource media=\\\"(max-width: 25em)\\\" srcset=\\\"https://video-images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1629811548581-team-cymru-marketing.png?resize=400:*, https://video-images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1629811548581-team-cymru-marketing.png?resize=600:* 2x\\\"\u003e\u003csource media=\\\"(max-width: 40.625em)\\\" srcset=\\\"https://video-images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1629811548581-team-cymru-marketing.png?resize=650:*, https://video-images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1629811548581-team-cymru-marketing.png?resize=975:* 2x\\\"\u003e\u003csource media=\\\"(max-width: 53.125em)\\\" srcset=\\\"https://video-images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1629811548581-team-cymru-marketing.png?resize=850:*, https://video-images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1629811548581-team-cymru-marketing.png?resize=1275:* 2x\\\"\u003e\u003csource media=\\\"(max-width: 65.625em)\\\" srcset=\\\"https://video-images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1629811548581-team-cymru-marketing.png?resize=1050:*, https://video-images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1629811548581-team-cymru-marketing.png?resize=1575:* 2x\\\"\u003e\u003csource media=\\\"(min-width: 65.625em)\\\" srcset=\\\"https://video-images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1629811548581-team-cymru-marketing.png?resize=1050:*, https://video-images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1629811548581-team-cymru-marketing.png?resize=1575:* 2x\\\"\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://video-images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1629811548581-team-cymru-marketing.png\\\" alt=\\\"team-cymru-marketing.png\\\"\u003e\u003c/picture\u003e\u003cdiv class=\\\"article__image-caption\\\"\u003eA section of Team Cymru's marketing material for its Pure Signal Recon product. Image: Team Cymru.\u003c/div\u003e\u003c/div\u003e \u003cp\u003eIn a \u003ca href=\\\"https://citizenlab.ca/2021/07/hooking-candiru-another-mercenary-spyware-vendor-comes-into-focus/\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003erecent research report\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e on an Israeli spyware vendor called Candiru, Citizen Lab thanked Team Cymru.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003e\\\"Thanks to Team Cymru for providing access to their Pure Signal Recon product. Their tool’s ability to show Internet traffic telemetry from the past three months provided the breakthrough we needed to identify the initial victim from Candiru’s infrastructure,\\\" the report reads. Citizen Lab did not respond to multiple requests for comment.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eTeam Cymru did not respond to multiple requests for comment on which ISPs provide it with the data, what privacy protections are in place around the collection and distribution of such data, and whether the individual ISP users have provided consent for their data to be shared.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp class=\\\"article__pull-quote\\\"\u003e\\\"Fundamentally, people have a right to some degree of anonymity, and as a carrier it's not our job to eavesdrop in any form.\\\"\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eFor its Cortex Xpanse product, Palo Alto Networks also gains access to netflow data, according to product documentation available online.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003e\\\"Cortex® Xpanse™ obtains flow data via multiple relationships with Tier 1 ISPs. Through these relationships, Cortex Xpanse has access to a sample of approximately 80% of global flows,\\\" \u003ca href=\\\"https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/cortex-xpanse/cortex-xpanse-user-guide/cortex-xpanse-expander/data/netflow-data.html\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eone page reads\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eJim Finkle, director of threat communications at Palo Alto Networks, said in an emailed statement that \\\"Palo Alto Networks provides enterprise customers with netflow data to and from their own networks to identify violations of security policies, gaps in security monitoring and other high-risk activity on the customer’s network.\\\" Palo Alto Networks declined to name which ISPs it sources data from, or whether it purchases the data outright from the ISPs.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eDave Schaeffer, CEO of ISP Cogent Communications, which he said handles around 22 percent of the world's internet traffic, told Motherboard that as an ISP his company doesn't provide their netflow data to anybody.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003e\\\"Fundamentally, people have a right to some degree of anonymity, and as a carrier it's not our job to eavesdrop in any form,\\\" he said in a phone call. Schaeffer says Cogent generates 96 percent of its traffic from selling to large wholesale customers, such as Vodafone, Cox, Spectrum, and BT. Schaeffer says Cogent provides services to Team Cymru but does not share netflow data with the company.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003e\\\"I don't know if there's a lot of really useful things people could do with [netflow] data,\\\" he added. \\\"There's probably some bad things I could think of if that data was available.\\\"\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eAlthough multiple sources were concerned about the sale of netflow data, several of them stressed that Team Cymru is a responsible organization.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003e\\\"It's pretty shadowy but honestly they're a 'good actor,'\\\" one in the threat intelligence industry said. \\\"Very strict protections on who can see it, but still, yeah, it's shady.\\\"\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eThe source familiar with the data said they were concerned about the sale of netflow data, but that Team Cymru \\\"also enable security organizations to do some really awesome work. So I'm conflicted about it.\\\"\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp class=\\\"article__pull-quote\\\"\u003e\\\"I'm concerned that netflow data being offered for commercial purposes is a path to a dark fucking place.\\\"\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eIn May, \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.vice.com/en/article/88ng8x/pentagon-americans-surveillance-without-warrant-internet-browsing\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eMotherboard reported that Senator Wyden's office\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e asked the Department of Defense (DoD), which includes various military and intelligence agencies such as the National Security Agency (NSA) and the Defense Intelligence Agency (DIA), for detailed information on its data purchasing practices. The response showed that the Pentagon is carrying out warrantless surveillance of Americans, according to a subsequent letter written by Wyden and obtained by Motherboard.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eSome of the answers the DoD provided were provided in a form meaning that Wyden's office could not legally publish specifics on the surveillance. Wyden's office then asked the DoD to release the information to the public. At the time, Wyden's office declined to provide Motherboard with specifics on one of the answers which was classified, but a Wyden aide said that the question related to the DoD buying internet metadata.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003e\\\"Are any DoD components buying and using without a court order internet metadata, including 'netflow' and Domain Name System (DNS) records,\\\" the question read.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eOther cybersecurity firms sell access to controversial datasets. In September, \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.vice.com/en/article/qj454d/private-intelligence-location-data-xmode-hyas\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eMotherboard reported how one firm called HYAS\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e was sourcing smartphone location data to trace people to their \\\"doorstep.\\\" As \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.vice.com/en/article/jgqm5x/us-military-location-data-xmode-locate-x\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eMotherboard has repeatedly shown\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e, the ordinary apps installed on peoples' phones that gather this information often don't have informed consent to then sell or otherwise provide it to third parties.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003e\u003ci\u003e\u003cb\u003eSubscribe to our cybersecurity podcast CYBER, \u003ca href=\\\"https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/cyber/id1441708044\\\" data that can, among other things, trace traffic through \",\"custom_neg_quit_us\",\"gs_politics_american\",\"gt_positive_curiosity\",\"gs_predicts_marketers\",\"gs_predicts_newjob\",\"custom_neg_dunkindonuts\",\"gs_predicts_small_med_bus\",\"gs_predicts_marchmadness\",\"custom_neg_lego_1\",\"gs_predicts_legal_industry\",\"custom_neg_merck_nuvaring\",\"gs_predicts_veteransservice\",\"gs_politics_misc\",\"gv_safe\"],\"word_count\":0,\"autoplay\":false,\"clickthrough_url\":null,\"social_description\":null,\"social_title\":null,\"hide_recirculation\":false,\"html_page_title\":null,\"age_required\":null,\"birthday_required\":null,\"email_subject_line\":null,\"short_title\":null,\"canonical_source\":null,\"no_index\":false,\"contains_nudity\":false,\"contains_profanity\":false,\"webflow_url\":null,\"show_product_grid\":false,\"hide_product_info\":false,\"content_policy_scoped_locales\":[{\"id\":\"57a204068cb727dec794c573\",\"label\":\"United Data Brokers Sell Access to the Backbone of the DHS, DOJ, and DOD, Senator Wyden writes that “my office was recently contacted by a whistleblower who described a series of formal complaints they filed up and down their chain of command, as well as to the DOD Inspector General and the Defense Intelligence Agency, regarding the warrantless purchase and use of netflow data by the Naval Criminal Investigative Service (NCIS).”\u0026nbsp;\",\"text\":\"In his letter addressed to the oversight departments of the DHS, DOJ, and DOD, Senator Wyden writes that \u0026#x201c;my office was recently contacted by a whistleblower who described a series of formal complaints they filed up and down their chain of command, as well as to the DOD Inspector General and the Defense Intelligence Agency, regarding the warrantless purchase and use of netflow data by the Naval Criminal Investigative Service (NCIS).\u0026#x201d;\",\"dropcap\":false,\"charscount\":458,\"wordscount\":75},{\"id\":\"63613d093d7f800093e2b1f4\",\"version\":\"1\",\"position\":30,\"role\":\"body\",\"html\":\"The whistleblower alleges that NCIS is purchasing data from Team Cymru that includes both “netflow records and some communications content,” the letter continues. “The whistleblower has informed my office that their complaint was forwarded by the DOD Inspector General to the Navy Inspector General.” Pointing to the various U.S. government contracts for access to Augury, which his office also reviewed, in his letter Senator Wyden asks the oversight branches of the DHS, DOJ, and DOD to “investigate the warrantless purchase and use of Americans’ internet browsing records by the agencies under your jurisdictions. Your independent oversight must ensure that the government’s surveillance activities are consistent with the Supreme Court’s Carpenter decision and safeguard Americans’ Fourth Amendment rights.”\u0026nbsp;\",\"text\":\"The whistleblower alleges that NCIS is purchasing data from Team Cymru that includes both \u0026#x201c;netflow records and some communications content,\u0026#x201d; the letter continues. \u0026#x201c;The whistleblower has informed my office that their complaint was forwarded by the DOD Inspector General to the Navy Inspector General.\u0026#x201d; Pointing to the various U.S. government contracts for access to Augury, which his office also reviewed, in his letter Senator Wyden asks the oversight branches of the DHS, DOJ, and DOD to \u0026#x201c;investigate the warrantless purchase and use of Americans\u0026#x2019; internet browsing records by the agencies under your jurisdictions. Your independent oversight must ensure that the government\u0026#x2019;s surveillance activities are consistent with the Supreme Court\u0026#x2019;s Carpenter decision and safeguard Americans\u0026#x2019; Fourth Amendment rights.\u0026#x201d;\",\"dropcap\":false,\"charscount\":912,\"wordscount\":140},{\"id\":\"63613d093d7f800093e2b1f5\",\"version\":\"1\",\"position\":31,\"role\":\"body\",\"html\":\"The Department of Defense Office of the Inspector General, which the whistleblower alleges referred their complaint to the Navy, told Motherboard it had received Wyden’s letter and was reviewing it. The Office of the Naval Inspector General declined to comment and directed Motherboard back to its Department of Defense counterpart.\",\"text\":\"The Department of Defense Office of the Inspector General, which the whistleblower alleges referred their complaint to the Navy, told Motherboard it had received Wyden\u0026#x2019;s letter and was reviewing it. The Office of the Naval Inspector General declined to comment and directed Motherboard back to its Department of Defense counterpart.\",\"dropcap\":false,\"charscount\":343,\"wordscount\":53},{\"id\":\"63613d093d7f800093e2b1f6\",\"version\":\"1\",\"position\":32,\"role\":\"body\",\"html\":\"Beyond his day job as CEO of Team Cymru, Rabbi Rob Thomas also sits on the board of the Tor Project, a privacy focused non-profit that maintains the Tor software. That software is what underpins the Tor anonymity network, \u003ca href=\\\"https://metrics.torproject.org/networksize.html\\\"\u003ea collection of thousands of volunteer-run servers\u003c/a\u003e that allow anyone to anonymously browse the internet.\u0026nbsp;\",\"text\":\"Beyond his day job as CEO of Team Cymru, Rabbi Rob Thomas also sits on the board of the Tor Project, a privacy focused non-profit that maintains the Tor software. That software is what underpins the Tor anonymity network, [a collection of thousands of volunteer-run servers](https://metrics.torproject.org/networksize.html) that allow anyone to anonymously browse the internet.\",\"dropcap\":false,\"charscount\":327,\"wordscount\":56},{\"id\":\"63613d093d7f800093e2b1f7\",\"version\":\"1\",\"position\":33,\"role\":\"body\",\"html\":\"“Just like Tor users, the developers, researchers, and founders who've made Tor possible are a diverse group of people. But all of the people who have been involved in Tor are united by a common belief: internet users should have private access to an uncensored web,” \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.torproject.org/about/history/\\\"\u003ethe Tor Project’s website reads\u003c/a\u003e.\u0026nbsp;\",\"text\":\"\u0026#x201c;Just like Tor users, the developers, researchers, and founders who've made Tor possible are a diverse group of people. But all of the people who have been involved in Tor are united by a common belief: internet users should have private access to an uncensored web,\u0026#x201d; [the Tor Project\u0026#x2019;s website reads](https://www.torproject.org/about/history/).\",\"dropcap\":false,\"charscount\":338,\"wordscount\":60},{\"id\":\"63613d093d7f800093e2b1f8\",\"version\":\"1\",\"position\":34,\"role\":\"body\",\"html\":\"When asked by Motherboard in April about Thomas’ position on the Tor Project board while also being the CEO of a company that sells a capability for attributing activity on the internet, Isabela Bagueros, executive director for the Tor Project, said in an email that “Rabbi Rob's potential conflicts of interest have been vetted according to the standard conflicts disclosure process required of all board members. Based on the board's understanding of Rabbi Rob's work with Team Cymru, the board has not identified any conflicts of interest.”\",\"text\":\"When asked by Motherboard in April about Thomas\u0026#x2019; position on the Tor Project board while also being the CEO of a company that sells a capability for attributing activity on the internet, Isabela Bagueros, executive director for the Tor Project, said in an email that \u0026#x201c;Rabbi Rob's potential conflicts of interest have been vetted according to the standard conflicts disclosure process required of all board members. Based on the board's understanding of Rabbi Rob's work with Team Cymru, the board has not identified any conflicts of interest.\u0026#x201d;\",\"dropcap\":false,\"charscount\":595,\"wordscount\":99},{\"id\":\"63613d093d7f800093e2b1f9\",\"version\":\"1\",\"position\":35,\"role\":\"body\",\"html\":\"Motherboard has previously revealed other data purchases by the U.S. military. In 2020, \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.vice.com/en/article/jgqm5x/us-military-location-data-xmode-locate-x\\\"\u003eMotherboard found that a Muslim prayer app\u003c/a\u003e downloaded more than 98 million times sold its location data to a broker called X-Mode. X-Mode, in turn, included U.S. military contractors among its clients. As part of that investigation, Motherboard also found that U.S. Special Operations Command had purchased Locate X, a surveillance tool based on location data harvested from ordinary apps. Last March, \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.vice.com/en/article/y3g97x/location-data-apps-drone-strikes-iowa-national-guard\\\"\u003eMotherboard reported that a military unit that conducts drone strikes\u003c/a\u003e bought Locate X too.\",\"text\":\"Motherboard has previously revealed other data purchases by the U.S. military. In 2020, [Motherboard found that a Muslim prayer app](https://www.vice.com/en/article/jgqm5x/us-military-location-data-xmode-locate-x) downloaded more than 98 million times sold its location data to a broker called X-Mode. X-Mode, in turn, included U.S. military contractors among its clients. As part of that investigation, Motherboard also found that U.S. Special Operations Command had purchased Locate X, a surveillance tool based on location data harvested from ordinary apps. Last March, [Motherboard reported that a military unit that conducts drone strikes](https://www.vice.com/en/article/y3g97x/location-data-apps-drone-strikes-iowa-national-guard) bought Locate X too.\",\"dropcap\":false,\"charscount\":581,\"wordscount\":92},{\"id\":\"63613d093d7f800093e2b1fa\",\"version\":\"1\",\"position\":36,\"role\":\"body\",\"html\":\"After Motherboard published some of those findings, Sen. Wyden asked the Department of Defense for more information about its data purchases. Some of the agency’s subsequent responses were given in a form that meant Wyden's office could not legally publish specifics on the surveillance; one answer in particular was classified. Instead, \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.vice.com/en/article/88ng8x/pentagon-americans-surveillance-without-warrant-internet-browsing\\\"\u003eWyden wrote in a second letter in May 2021 to the agency\u003c/a\u003e: “I write to urge you to release to the public information about the Department of Defense's (DoD) warrantless surveillance of Americans,” suggesting that the Pentagon is engaged in such surveillance. At the time, Wyden's office declined to provide Motherboard with specifics about the classified answer. But a Wyden aide said that the question related to the Department of Defense buying internet metadata.\",\"text\":\"After Motherboard published some of those findings, Sen. Wyden asked the Department of Defense for more information about its data purchases. Some of the agency\u0026#x2019;s subsequent responses were given in a form that meant Wyden's office could not legally publish specifics on the surveillance; one answer in particular was classified. Instead, [Wyden wrote in a second letter in May 2021 to the agency](https://www.vice.com/en/article/88ng8x/pentagon-americans-surveillance-without-warrant-internet-browsing): \u0026#x201c;I write to urge you to release to the public information about the Department of Defense's (DoD) warrantless surveillance of Americans,\u0026#x201d; suggesting that the Pentagon is engaged in such surveillance. At the time, Wyden's office declined to provide Motherboard with specifics about the classified answer. But a Wyden aide said that the question related to the Department of Defense buying internet metadata.\",\"dropcap\":false,\"charscount\":854,\"wordscount\":137},{\"id\":\"63613d093d7f800093e2b1fb\",\"version\":\"1\",\"position\":37,\"role\":\"body\",\"html\":\"In August, the House of Representatives approved changes to next year’s military budget that would require the Department of Defense to start to disclose any purchases of web browsing or smartphone data that would ordinarily require a warrant, \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https://gizmodo.com/pentagon-budget-force-data-purchase-disclosure-ndaa-1849432085\\\"\u003eGizmodo \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https://gizmodo.com/pentagon-budget-force-data-purchase-disclosure-ndaa-1849432085\\\"\u003ereported at the time\u003c/a\u003e. It has yet to be approved by the Senate.\",\"text\":\"In August, the House of Representatives approved changes to next year\u0026#x2019;s military budget that would require the Department of Defense to start to disclose any purchases of web browsing or smartphone data that would ordinarily require a warrant, _[Gizmodo](https://gizmodo.com/pentagon-budget-force-data-purchase-disclosure-ndaa-1849432085)_ [reported at the time](https://gizmodo.com/pentagon-budget-force-data-purchase-disclosure-ndaa-1849432085). It has yet to be approved by the Senate.\",\"dropcap\":false,\"charscount\":325,\"wordscount\":55},{\"id\":\"63613d093d7f800093e2b1fc\",\"version\":\"1\",\"position\":38,\"role\":\"body\",\"html\":\"Other cybersecurity companies also package controversial datasets. In 2020 \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.vice.com/en/article/qj454d/private-intelligence-location-data-xmode-hyas\\\"\u003eMotherboard reported that HYAS\u003c/a\u003e, a threat intelligence firm, sourced location data in order to track people to their “doorstep.”\",\"text\":\"Other cybersecurity companies also package controversial datasets. In 2020 [Motherboard reported that HYAS](https://www.vice.com/en/article/qj454d/private-intelligence-location-data-xmode-hyas), a threat intelligence firm, sourced location data in order to track people to their \u0026#x201c;doorstep.\u0026#x201d;\",\"dropcap\":false,\"charscount\":223,\"wordscount\":31},{\"id\":\"63613d093d7f800093e2b1fd\",\"version\":\"1\",\"position\":39,\"role\":\"body\",\"html\":\"\u003cem\u003eUpdate: This piece has been updated with a statement from the Navy.\u003c/em\u003e\",\"text\":\"_Update: This piece has been updated with a statement from the Navy._\",\"dropcap\":false,\"charscount\":68,\"wordscount\":12},{\"id\":\"63613d093d7f800093e2b1fe\",\"version\":\"1\",\"position\":40,\"role\":\"body\",\"html\":\"\u003cem\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThis article is part of\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.vice.com/en/topic/state-of-surveillance-2022\\\"\u003eState of Surveillance\u003c/a\u003e, made possible with the support of a grant from Columbia University’s Ira A.
